newsitem.title: UK: European firms launch stealth warship designs.
newsitem.headline: European firms launch stealth warship designs.

text.p: Two European firms are vying for launch customers to buy the next generation stealth warship with the launch of two rival designs at the Euronaval '96 exhibition in Paris this week.

In the battle for exports both British naval shipyard Vosper Thornycroft and Anglo-French joint venture BAeSema have targeted the coastal patrol market with concepts which imitate the sinisterly angular designs of U.S. stealth aircraft.
"Obviously the name of the game nowadays is stealth -- denying your potential enemies' recognition," said Vosper Thornycroft's spokesman Phil Rood.

Rood said the prototype could be on the water in five years' time, but Vosper first needs to find a launch customer, and in the absence of any immediate requirement from the British Royal Navy it is looking overseas for a buyer.
"This is mainly an export ship...A lot of middle east and far east navies need ships of this size," he said.
Vosper says its Sea Wraith design not only reduces radar reflections but also enables the ship to vary its radar profile to confuse the enemy and baffle incoming radar-guided missiles.

In addition Vosper said it has devised a system for disguising the ship in a fine water mist which would also reduce 'hot spots' on the ship such as the exhaust to help protect the vessel from heat-seeking missiles.
BAeSema's rival Project Cougar corvette design is also characterised by a distinctive stealth profile and features a high-speed waterjet propulsion system to help avoid detection.
BAeSema is owned by British Aerospace and Sema Group Plc SA.
